com.googlecode.objectify.util.cmd

Class QueryWrapper<H extends QueryWrapper<H,T>,T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.googlecode.objectify.util.cmd.SimpleQueryWrapper<H,T>
      • com.googlecode.objectify.util.cmd.QueryWrapper<H,T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.google.appengine.api.datastore.QueryResultIterable<T>, Query<T>, QueryExecute<T>, SimpleQuery<T>, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<T>

    public class QueryWrapper<H extends QueryWrapper<H,T>,T>
extends SimpleQueryWrapper<H,T>
implements Query<T>
    Simple wrapper/decorator for a Query. Use it like this: class MyQuery<T> extends QueryWrapper<MyQuery<T>, T>
    Author:
    Jeff Schnitzer

    • Method Detail

      • filter

        public H filter(java.lang.String condition,
       java.lang.Object value)
        Description copied from interface: Query

        Create a filter based on the specified condition and value, using the same syntax as the GAE/Python query class. Examples:

        • filter("age >=", age)
        • filter("age =", age)
        • filter("age", age) (if no operator, = is assumed)
        • filter("age !=", age)
        • filter("age in", ageList)

        The space between the property name and the operator is required. Filtering a condition of "age>=" will perform an equality test on an entity property exactly named "age>=". You can't create properties like this with Objectify, but you can with the Low-Level API.

        See the Google documentation for indexes for an explanation of what you can and cannot filter for.

        In addition to filtering on indexed properties, you can filter on @Id properties if this query is restricted to a Class which has no @Parent. This is a convenient alias for filterKey() which builds the key for you.

        You can not filter on @Parent properties. Use filterKey() or ancestor() instead.

        Specified by:
        filter in interface Query<T>

      • order

        public H order(java.lang.String condition)
        Description copied from interface: Query

        Sorts based on a property. Examples:

        • order("age")
        • order("-age") (descending sort)

        You can sort on @Id properties if this query is restricted to a Class which has no @Parent. Note that this is only important for descending sorting; default iteration is key-ascending.

        You can not sort on @Parent properties.

        Specified by:
        order in interface Query<T>
